Package aips.search

Interface State

public interface State
This interface defines the methods required on a problem state. Any class that represents a problem state must implement this interface.
Author:
K. Hui

  • Method Summary

    Modifier and Type Method Description
    boolean equals​(java.lang.Object state)
    Checks if two states are equal.
    int hashCode()
    Calculate the hash code of a state.
    java.util.List<ActionStatePair> successor()
    This is the successor function which generates all action-states of a state when it is expanded.
    java.lang.String toString()
    Return the state into a printable String.

  • Method Details

    • toString

      java.lang.String toString()
      Return the state into a printable String. You should customise this method for your state so that it return a String which can be easily printed in the console.
      Overrides:
      toString in class java.lang.Object
      Returns:
      A String representation of the state.

    • equals

      boolean equals​(java.lang.Object state)
      Checks if two states are equal. This method is used when we check for repeated states in the history, and see if we have reached a goal state. As our problem states are represented by Java (or Python) objects, they may be 2 different State objects but with the same attribute values. Two states are consider "equal" if they have the same attribute values. e.g. the case of 2 twins. If you get this wrong for your State class, the search may fall into an infinite loop (as it cannot see a repeated state), or fail to recognise a goal when it reaches one.
      Overrides:
      equals in class java.lang.Object
      Parameters:
      state - The other state to compare with.
      Returns:
      true if the current state and the other are the same (value-wise). false otherwise.

    • hashCode

      int hashCode()
      Calculate the hash code of a state. This method is needed because internally we are using a HashSet to store the history (of states), and the Set.contains(Object) method of the HashSet to check if a state is in the history. For this to work correctly in Java, the object (i.e. State) to be stored into the HashSet must have a int hashCode() method defined. The key requirement is for objects which are equal (e.g. all attribute values are the same) to have the same hash code. The hash code is usually calculated based on the attribute values of the object.
      Overrides:
      hashCode in class java.lang.Object
      Returns:
      The hash code of the State object.

    • successor

      java.util.List<ActionStatePair> successor()
      This is the successor function which generates all action-states of a state when it is expanded. This method must be tailored for each domain. The returned result is a List of ActionStatePair objects. It is a list, not a set as we want to keep the order of the children nodes. If use a Set, the order is not kept/guaranteed.
      Returns:
      All possible action-state pairs as a List of ActionStatePair objects.
